results.name: Abelsonite
results.description_short: Chemically a nickel porphyrine derivative, classified as deoxophylloerythroetioporphyrin. Unique combination of elements; the only organonickel mineral known. Formed at depth (Milton et al., 1978), likely from a chlorophyll (but likely not the chloroph...
results.tlform: Aggregates of platy crystals; as patches, sometimes over 2 mm in diameter.
results.occurrence: Mahogany Zone oil shale; found in six stratigraphical zones ( M9, M7, M2, L6, L0, and K1); its genesis is connected with unique geochemical conditions of Lake Uinta; likely formed due to chlorophyll diagenesis; abelsonite's relatively insoluble precursor was likely transported by an aqueous solution towards sediments of favorable lithology.
results.otheroccurrence:
Small aggregates, to 1 cm, of thin laths or
plates. Of secondary origin on fracture surfaces in oil shale.
results.colour: Pink-purple, dark greyish purple, pale purplish red, reddish brown
results.aboutname: For American physicist Philip Hauge Abelson (27 April 1913, Tacoma, Washington, USA - 1 August 2004, Bethesda, Maryland, USA). He was co-discoverer of element 93 (neptunium), editor of the periodical Science (1962-1984), and director of the Carnegie Institution of Washington's Geophysical Laboratory (1953-1971).
results.other: UV-Vis bands [nm]: 392, 510, 550 in benzene or 390, 512, and 552 in acetone (suggestible for deoxophylloerythroetioporphyrin with an isocyclic ring); also 618 band present, suggesting presence of some free-base porphyrin
results.type_specimen_store:
The Natural History Museum, London, England, number 1979,135.
National Museum of Natural History, Washington, D.C., USA, numbers 143566, 145712.

results.name: Abenakiite-(Ce)
results.description_short:
Unique chemistry (the only Na-REE-Si-P-C mineral). Chemistry comparable to that of steenstrupine-(Ce).

Currently the only mineral with a supposed sulphur dioxide inclusion. Originally a single grain was found, making the mineral exceedingly rare. 
...
results.tlform: A single grain, 2 x 1 mm in size.
results.occurrence: In a xenolith of sodalite syenite. A late-stage phase, possibly arising from a metasomatic event associated with emplacement of the nepheline syenite.
results.aboutname: Named after the Abenaki, the indigenous people who inhabited the area around Mont Saint-Hilaire in southern Qu√©bec and the North-Eastern USA, prior to the arrival of European settlers.  The suffix/modifier indicates that the predominant essential REE is cerium.
results.other: A very weak effervescence in 1:1 HCl.
results.type_specimen_store: Canadian Museum of Nature, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada,  #81501.

results.name: Abernathyite
results.description_short:
Meta-autunite Group. Chemically the As analogue of meta-ankoleite (both crystallize in the same point group).

A rare secondary uranium mineral.
results.aboutname: Named by M. E. Thompson, B. Ingram, and E. B. Gross in 1956 after Jesse Evrett Abernathy (September 7, 1913 - November 5, 1963, Moab, UT, USA), amateur mineralogist and lapidarist and operator of the Fumarole mine.
results.type_specimen_store: National Museum of Natural History, Washington, DC, USA

results.name: Actinolite
results.description_short: Actinolite  is an intermediate member Actinolite-Tremolite Series.  Tremolite is defined as having an Mg/(Mg+Fe2+) ratio ‚â• 0.9; actinolite has a ratio of 0.5‚Äì0.9 and ferro-actinolite has a ratio of less than 0.5. The name actinolite has been retained f...
results.otheroccurrence:
Produced by low-grade regional or contact metamorphism of magnesium carbonate, mafic, or ultramafic rocks; Also in glaucophane-bearing blueschists.  

Occurs in many localities. In Austria, on Mt. Greiner, Zillertal, and at Untersulzbachtal. From Zermatt, Valais, Switzerland. At Snarum and Arendal, Norway. From the Ural Mountains, Russia. In the USA, from Gouverneur, St. Lawrence Co., New York; Franklin and Newton, Sussex Co., New Jersey; Chester, Windsor Co., Vermont; in the Fairfax quarry, Centreville, Fairfax Co., Virginia; Crestmore, Riverside Co., California; at Salida, Chaffee Co., Colorado. Nephrite jade occurs, in the USA, south and east of Lander, Fremont Co., Wyoming; north from Cape San Martin, Monterey Co., California; and around Jade Mountain, near the Kobuk River, Alaska. Along the Fraser River, British Columbia, Canada. Around Mt. Cook, South Island, New Zealand. Fine material from the Kunlun Mountains, Sinkiang Uighur Autonomous Region, China.
results.aboutname:
Named in 1794 by Richard Kirwan from the Greek Œ±Œ∫œÑŒØŒΩŒ± ("aktina") for "ray" and ŒªŒØŒ∏ŒøœÇ ("lithos") for "stone" in allusion to the fibrous nature of the original specimens. 
Type locality not known.
results.twinning: simple or lamellar, common parallel {100}; lamellar,  less common parallel {001}
results.opticalpleochorismdesc:
X= pale yellow, yellowish green
Y= pale yellow-green, green
Z= pale green, deep greenish blue
results.commentcolor: Colourless, pale green to deep green in thin section.

results.name: Acuminite
results.description_short:
An aluminum complex salt. Only found in two cavities in a single specimen 10.5 cm across.

Chemically identical and structurally similar to tikhonenkovite.

Structure details (Krogh Andersen et al., 1991): SrF7(H2O)2 and  AlF4(OH)2 polyhedra link t...
results.tlform: Acute dipyramidal crystals, resembling spear points, to 1 mm.
results.occurrence: Strontium-rich portion of a cryolite deposit.
results.colour: Colourless, white, becomes yellow on exposure to x-rays
results.aboutname: From Latin "acumen", "spearhead", in allusion to the shape of its crystals.
results.other: Becomes yellow on exposure to X-rays.

results.name: Adamite
results.description_short:
Olivenite Group. Adamite-Olivenite Series. 
The orthorhombic dimorph of Paradamite. The Zn analogue of Olivenite.

In terms of chemistry, but not structure, adamite is an arsenic equivalent (stoichiometrically similar to) of tarbuttite. The two mine...
results.otheroccurrence: A secondary mineral in the oxidised zone of zinc- and arsenic-bearing hydrothermal mineral deposits.
results.colour: Ideally white, colourless, frequently pale yellow, honey-yellow, brownish yellow, rose red; blue, pale green to green, may be zoned; bright green (Cu-bearing); bright pink, purple (Co-bearing)
results.opticalextinction: X = a; Y = c; Z = b.
results.aboutname: Named by Charles Friedel in 1866 for Gilbert Joseph Adam (7 April 1795 Seine-et-Marne, Fontainbleau, France - 8 June 1881 Paris, France), Inspector (Auditor) of Finance for the French Government, who supplied the first specimens of his mineral. Adam was a wealthy mineral collector and his mineral collection was described in Annales des Mines in 1869 and later in a published catalog (1869). Adam was also the discoverer of aerugite, chenevixite, corkite, cuprotungstite, scacchite, and xanthiosite. Adam's mineral collection was acquired by the √âcole des Mines, Paris, France. Adam was a member of Soci√©t√© g√©ologique de France and received the honor of Commandeur de la L√©gion d'Honneur.
results.morphology: Crystals of variable morphology. Often elongated [010], also elongated [001], rarely elongated [100]. Tabular at times {101} or equant. Commonly forms radial aggregates, fanlike rosettes or crystalline crusts.
results.opticaldispersion: strong r > v or r < v
results.opticalpleochorismdesc: In pale colours if cuprian or cobaltian.
results.uv: May fluoresce or phosphoresce lemon-yellow under SW and LW UV.
results.type_specimen_store:
Ecole Nationale Sup√©rieure des Mines, Paris, France, number 16976.
Mus√©um Nationale d‚ÄôHistoire Naturelle, Paris, France, number 66.34.
results.thermalbehaviour: Heated in a closed tube, it decrepitates feebly, and gives a little water, becoming white and porcelanous. On  charcoal, it fuses, producing a coating of zinc oxide, and a faint odor of arsenic. In a closed tube with soda and charcoal, it gives a ring of arsenic.
results.commentcolor: Colourless or faintly tinted in transmitted light.

results.name: Adelite
results.description_short:
Adelite-Descloizite Group. Adelite-Gottlobite Series. 
The arsenate analogue of Gottlobite.

Crystal structure details (Effenberger et al., 2002): M2 site is Mg; there are (M2)O6 octahedra that share edges to form chains; the chains are parallel to ...
results.occurrence: A rare mineral in a metamorphosed Fe‚ÄìMn orebody
results.otheroccurrence: On willemite-franklinite ore from a metamorphosed stratiform zinc orebody (Franklin, New Jersey, USA).
results.colour: Colourless, white, grey, bluish grey, yellowish grey, yellow, pale green, pinkish brown, brown
results.aboutname: Named by Hjalmar Sj√∂gren in 1891 from the Greek Œ¨Œ¥Œ∑ŒªŒøœÇ for "adelos," "obscure" or "indistinct", in reference to its lack of transparency.
results.type_specimen_store: Swedish Museum of Natural History, Stockholm, Sweden, number HS 6413.

results.name: Admontite
results.tlform: poorly developed or corroded crystals to ca. 1 mm; [001] elongation, {100} flattening
results.aboutname: Named after its discovery locality, at Schildmauer near Admont, Austria.
results.morphology: Crystals are poorly developed or corroded, to about 1 mm, elongated along <mi>[001]</mi>, flattened parallel to <mi>{100}</mi>.

results.name: Aerinite
results.mindat_formula_note: According to Rius et al. (2009), the formula of the Fe<sup>3+</sup>-rich variety includes SO<sub>3</sub> (sulphite) substitution for carbonate.
results.description_short:
A rare, chemically complex carbonate-bearing silicate. Found as a pigment in European murals.

NB: Some of the recorded Spanish localities for aerinite seem to be in reality misidentified riebeckite-magnesioriebeckite, especially for localities not i...
results.otheroccurrence: A hydrothermal mineral of the zeolite facies, formed at relatively low temperature, in fractures cutting mafic igneous rocks.
results.aboutname: From the Greek "aerinos," for sky-blue, alluding to its color.
results.morphology: As masses of cryptocrystalline fibers; earthy, compact.
results.type_specimen_store:
Wroclaw University, Wroclaw, Poland; 
National School of Mines, Paris, France.
results.commentcrystal: Originally assumed to be monoclinic, a = 14.69 ‚Ñ´, b = 16.87 ‚Ñ´, c = 5.17 ‚Ñ´, Œ≤ = 94.75¬∞.

results.name: Aerugite
results.occurrence: Oxidised vein in a nickel arsenic deposit.
results.otheroccurrence: A rare secondary mineral in hydrothermal Ni‚ÄìAs‚ÄìU ore deposits.
results.aboutname: Named by Gilbert-Joseph Adam in 1869 from 'aerugo', which means 'copper rust', alluding to its appearance.
results.morphology: Fine-grained crystalline, massive, as crusts, to 2 mm thick.
results.type_specimen_store: Natural History Museum, London, England, 32590 and 1907,103.
